user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketListen:
```c
int32 OS_SocketListen(osal_id_t sock_id)
{
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *stream;
    OS_object_token_t            token;
    int32                        return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sock_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        stream = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, token);

        /* This call is only applicable to stream sockets */
        if (stream->socket_domain == OS_SocketDomain_INVALID || stream->socket_type != OS_SocketType_STREAM)
        {
            /* Not a stream socket */
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE;
        }
        else if ((stream->stream_state & OS_STREAM_STATE_BOUND) == 0)
        {
            /* Socket must be bound to an address already */
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
        }
        else if ((stream->stream_state & (OS_STREAM_STATE_LISTENING | OS_STREAM_STATE_CONNECTED)) != 0)
        {
            /* Socket must be neither listening nor connected */
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
        }
        else
        {
            return_code = OS_SocketListen_Impl(&token);

            if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
            {
                stream->stream_state |= OS_STREAM_STATE_LISTENING;
            }
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketListen:
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_stream_internal_record_t OS_stream_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct
{
    char   stream_name[OS_MAX_PATH_LEN];
    uint8  socket_domain;
    uint8  socket_type;
    uint16 stream_state;
} OS_stream_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
int32 OS_SocketListen_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                             os_result;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    os_result = listen(impl->fd, 10);
    if (os_result < 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("listen: %s\n", strerror(errno));
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE (-36)
...
#define OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE (-35)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I have flagged the macro definition and all sites where that macro is used with a token-like argument, plus the functions that take OS_object_token_t * / const OS_object_token_t * parameters. These fragments merit inspection because taking the address of a token object (via the macro) and passing token values around can enable other routines to modify either the pointer variable or the pointed-to object; they are the locations where Rule 17.8 violations are most likely to occur.

Other fragments in the provided code do not need investigation for Rule 17.8 because they do not modify function pointer parameters themselves: the checks and assignments such as stream->stream_state |= OS_STREAM_STATE_LISTENING modify the object pointed to (the stream record), which is allowed by the rule. The non-pointer parameter sock_id is not modified. Calls that pass the token pointer (not its address) only allow modification of the pointee, which is permitted. No other function in the shown code reassigns a pointer parameter variable (i.e., there are no occurrences of statements like `token = ...`, `token++`, or taking the address of a pointer-parameter variable and then modifying it) aside from the places already listed above.
